Some notes:

The default compiler in the latest of Precise upgrades [12.04.4](https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PrecisePangolin/ReleaseNotes/UbuntuDesktop) is gcc-4.6.3 and this is the [latest of the upgrades](https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PrecisePangolin/ReleaseSchedule) on 12.04.

gcc 4.6 does not have the the c++11 flag but c++0x. The support for [C++11 features is limited](http://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-4.6/cxx0x_status.html). The first series that can implement the full standard is 4.8, not very difficult to install on Precise using the toolchain PPA, but not in a default system.

The point is: how dangerous is to link software compiled with c++98 and c++11? [There is a full page about ABI compatibility](http://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Cxx11AbiCompatibility). The [point](http://stackoverflow.com/a/6494173) seems to be in the data types used by the interfaces, specially if using standard library data types (for example std::string). 

In the other hand we have Ubuntu 12.04 with support until 2017 so waiting so long does not look as the best option to me.
